event_registry_properties.name: action
event_registry_properties.item: The administrator should review the ILOM event log for additional information pertaining to this diagnosis. Please refer to the Details section of the Knowledge Article for additional information.
event_registry_properties.name: description
event_registry_properties.item: A Memory DIMM's temperature sensor has failed.
event_registry_properties.name: details
event_registry_properties.item:
Details
Message ID: SPX86-8001-QX indicates that the ILOM fault manager has received an
error report indicating that a memory DIMM's temperature sensor has failed a circuit test.

At host power-on, BIOS passes control to the Memory Reference Code (MRC) software for processors,
Intel QuickPath Interconnect (QPI),  Intel 5500 chipset (IOH/ICH), and memory initialization.  
MRC performs a significant level of testing and diagnosis, and applies Intel-defined policies to
failures in the memory subsystem, thereby mapping out DIMM(s) that it has determined either faulty,
misconfigured, or otherwise unusable.

Closed Loop Thermal Throttling (CLTT) was requested, but cannot be performed
because the DIMM failed the temperature sensor circuit test.

MRC has determined that a DIMM is no longer protected by closed loop thermal throttling (CLTT).

The  memory DIMM will be used and is enabled.

BIOS forwards error telemetry to the SP for diagnosis and logging in ILOM event log.

The service-required LED indicator next to the DIMM that had a failed temperature sensor will be illuminated.
When equipped, a "fault remind" button on the motherboard illuminates this LED when depressed.
The ILOM CLI will display status of the memory DIMM LED indicator as: /SYS/MB/Px/Dy/SERVICE = On
Refer to the service label located on top cover for the location of memory DIMM and the "Fault Remind" button.

The chassis-wide service required LED on the rackmount server or blade server will also be illuminated.
The ILOM CLI will display the status of the chassis-wide LED indicator as:  /SYS/SERVICE = On

The recommended service action for this event is to replace the faulty memory DIMM.



The recommended service actions for this event are as follows:

      Section A -  Identify Faulty Component / FRU
      Section B -  Contact Authorized Service Provider
      Section C -  Clearing Fault after DIMM Replacement


      LEGEND
      GREEN =  FRU
      BLUE    =  EVENT_ID
      RED      =  SUNW-MSG-ID



Section A -  Identify Faulty Component / FRU


   Login to the ILOM command line interface as 'root' and use the following commands to identify the faulty component / FRU.
  The sample output shown below in steps A1-A3 identify the suspect FRU as "/SYS/MB/P0/D2",
   which represents the full physical path to FRU,  whereby "SYS" represents the chassis,
   "MB" represents motherboard, "P0" represents processor, and "D2" represents memory DIMM.
   Refer to either the service label on top cover or silk screen labeling on the motherboard to locate DIMM "D2".


          Step A1.  List all known faults in the system

                       Example:
                       -> show /SP/faultmgmt  

                        /SP/faultmgmt
                          Targets:
                              0 (/SYS/MB/P0/D2)   
       
                          Properties:

                          Commands:
                              cd
                              show


          Step A2.  List the state of the faulted memory DIMM

                       Example:
                       -> show /SYS/MB/P0/D2  

                      /SYS/MB/P0/D2
                           Targets:
                              PRSNT
                              SERVICE

                           Properties:
                              type = DIMM
                              fru_name = 2GB DDR3 SDRAM 533
                              fru_manufacturer = Micron Technology
                              fru_version = 445a
                              fru_part_number = 18JSF25672PY-1G1DZ
                              fru_serial_number = EA05F2E8
                              fault_state = Faulted
                              clear_fault_action = (none)

                           Commands:
                              cd
                              show

          
          Step A3.  List the contents of the ILOM event log

                       Example:
                       -> show /SP/logs/event/list
        
                       6169   Sat Dec 27 08:26:35 2008  Fault     Fault     critical
                       Fault detected at time =  Sat Dec 27 08:26:35 2008.
                       The suspect component: /SYS/MB/P0/D2 has fault.memory.intel.dimm.tempsensor-failed with probability=100.
                       Refer to http://www.sun.com/msg/SPX86-8001-QX for details.

  
    The recommended service action for this event is to replace the faulty memory DIMM.


                Sun Fire X2270

                     The memory DIMM is customer serviceable.
                     There are 6 DIMM slots per CPU.

                     To achieve optimal performance;

                         1.  Install DIMMs in groups of 3.
            
                                    1st Set    D5, D3, D1
                                    2nd Set   D4, D2, D0
  
                         2. If not installing DIMMs in groups of 3, always install DIMMs in descending order
                             within a color/group (e.g., two DIMMs would be installed in D5 & D3).
  
                         3. Quad-Rank (QR) DIMMs should always be installed first.
 
                         4.  When QR DIMMs are in use on a channel, then leave the black slot empty.

                 

                Sun Fire X4170
                Sun Fire X4270
                Sun Fire X4275

                      The AC power cords connected to the power supplies must be detached,  prior to removing
                      the top cover to access the DIMM's.  Failure to do so will result in a chassis intrusion failure
                      and potential cause damage to the DIMM's.
               
                      The memory DIMM is customer serviceable.
                      There are 9 DIMM slots per CPU.

                      To achieve optimal performance;

                         1.  Install DIMMs in groups of 3.
            
                                    1st Set    D8, D5, D2
                                    2nd Set   D7, D4, D1
                                    3rd Set    D6, D3, D0
  
                         2. If not installing DIMMs in groups of 3, always install DIMMs in descending order
                             within a color/group (e.g., two DIMMs would be installed in D8 & D5).
  
                         3. Quad-Rank (QR) DIMMs should always be installed first.
 
                         4.  When QR DIMMs are in use on a channel, then leave the black slot empty.



                Sun Blade X6270

                     The memory DIMM is customer serviceable.
                     There are 9 DIMM slots per CPU.

                     To achieve optimal performance;

                         1.  Install DIMMs in groups of 3.
            
                                    1st Set    D8, D5, D2
                                    2nd Set   D7, D4, D1
                                    3rd Set    D6, D3, D0
  
                         2. If not installing DIMMs in groups of 3, always install DIMMs in descending order
                             within a color/group (e.g., two DIMMs would be installed in D8 & D5).
  
                         3. Quad-Rank (QR) DIMMs should always be installed first.
 
                         4.  When QR DIMMs are in use on a channel, then leave the black slot empty.



                Sun Blade X6275
                  
                     The memory DIMM is customer serviceable.
                     There are 6 DIMM slots per CPU.

                     To achieve optimal performance;

                         1.  Install DIMMs in groups of 3.
            
                                    1st Set    D5, D3, D1
                                    2nd Set   D4, D2, D0
  
                         2. If not installing DIMMs in groups of 3, always install DIMMs in descending order
                             within a color/group (e.g., two DIMMs would be installed in D5 & D3).
  
                         3. Quad-Rank (QR) DIMMs should always be installed first.
 
                         4.  When QR DIMMs are in use on a channel, then leave the black slot empty.

           
                 
         Proceed to Step C1, located in Section C, to determine how to clear fault on a memory DIMM after replacement.




Section B -   Contact Authorized Service Provider


      Please contact your service provider in accordance with the terms and conditions of your service
      agreement to open a service request and to confirm and carry out the required repair actions specified
      by current service policy.

      Your service provider may ask for information displayed using the procedures outlined in Section A.
     
      If the product is covered by a current service agreement with Sun Microsystems, Inc.,
      please refer to the following  instructions for reporting the problem and opening a service request. 


            Auto Service Request (ASR) Activated for the Product

               If ASR has been activated for the product on which this problem was diagnosed, you have,
               or will receive a notification via e-mail confirming a service request has been automatically
               opened along with instructions for viewing the service request.

               All of the fault event telemetry required to open a service request has already been transmitted
               to Sun Services. Unless contacted and instructed otherwise by a Sun Service representative,
               no further actions is required to report this problem to Sun Microsystems.

               The e-mail notification will provide a pointer back to this same article.
              
               If you are reading this article in response to a fault message or SNMP trap generated on the product,
               rather than in response to the ASR notification e-mail above, then you can check on the status of the
               associated service request by logging into the Members Support Center at  http://sun.com/support 

               For more information on Auto Service Request (ASR) and the currently supported products,
               please refer to http://sun.com/service/asr



             Submitting a Service Request via the Members Support Center Portal

                In cases where ASR has not been activated:

                      1.  Login to the Members Support Center at  http://sun.com/support
         
                      2.  Create a Service Request

                      3.  Copy and paste the information displayed using the instructions provided in Section A
                           to identify the faulty FRU(s), into the Service Request notes.




Section C -  Clearing Fault after DIMM Replacement


         The steps that are necessary to clear a fault are largely dependent on the type of server platform (blade vs rackmount).


             Blade Servers
      
                ILOM-based faults that occur on a Blade server are NOT  persistent once the blade has been
                properly prepared for removal and is physically removed from the chassis,
                therefore no service action to clear the fault is necessary after the FRU is physically replaced.
   

             Rackmount Servers
      
                ILOM-based faults that occur on a Rackmount server ARE  persistent and require service
                actions to clear the fault after the FRU/component is physically replaced.
            
             

         The following provides guidance as to what steps are necessary to clear a fault after DIMM replacement.


                Sun Fire X2270
                Sun Fire X4170
                Sun Fire X4270
                Sun Fire X4275

                      Step C1  is required on this server running any operating system.


                Sun Blade X6270
                Sun Blade X6275

                      Step C1  is NOT required on this server running any operating system.




          Step C1.  Use ILOM Command Line Interface (CLI) to Clear Fault
               
                Login to the ILOM command line interface as 'root' and use the following commands to clear the fault.

                        Example:
                       -> set /SYS/MB/P0/D2 clear_fault_action=true
                       Are you sure you want to clear /SYS/MB/P0/D2 (y/n)?  y
                       Set 'clear_fault_action' to 'true'
event_registry_properties.name: impact
event_registry_properties.item: DIMM will be used and enabled, but will no longer be protected by closed loop thermal throttling (CLTT).
event_registry_properties.name: response
title
